docs.lead_paragraph: The National Football League could soon face one of its most difficult challenges, as an association made up of dozens of head coaches and hundreds of assistants is preparing to file a lawsuit against the league early next month seeking improved working conditions and benefits. While there remains a solid chance the situation will soon be settled without court action, several owners and members of the association believe a legal battle may be imminent.

headline.main: Coaches Group Threatens to File Suit for Better Benefits

docs.abstract: Members of National Football League Coaches Assn, which represents 18 head coaches and more than 400 assistant coaches, prepares to file suit against National Football League seeking improved working conditions and benefits for assistant coaches; photo (M)

headline.main: In the Event, Red Bank Is Ready

docs.abstract: Article on expertise with which special events committee in Redbank, NJ, prepare each year for eight major summer festivals, which are attracting larger crowds each season; photos (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: VOTERS in Uniondale go to the polls on Tuesday facing a proposed school budget that would raise the average homeowner's taxes by $250. ''We know how this increase will be read,'' said Gene Levenstien, the district's assistant superintendent for business. ''But it is literally a bare-bones budget.''

headline.main: Schools Warily Await Votes On Large Budget Increases

docs.abstract: School districts throughout Long Island are proposing unusually large budget increases, which are about to be put before voters; officials insist sharp increases are needed to service earlier capital improvement bonds, meet state's new academic standards and rising student enrollment; photo; chart (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: It was one of the more astonishing political images of the year: a newspaper advertisement that linked Osama bin Laden, the suspected international terrorist, with Senator Spencer Abraham, the Michigan Republican. Why is the senator, asked the advertisement that ran in some of Michigan's largest newspapers, ''trying to make it easier for terrorists like Osama bin Laden to export their way of terror to any street in America?''

headline.main: Special-Interest Groups Widening Political Attack Ads

docs.abstract: Special-interest groups widen political attack ads in elections around country; examples include Michigan commercials by anti-immigrant group FAIR against Sen Spencer Abraham, and Handgun Control's spots implying that if George W Bush is elected president NRA will work out of Oval Office; photos (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: THE three-story Tudor on tree-graced Maryland Road in Douglaston, Queens, often reverberates with the clamor and clatter of Frances Toner's dozen grandchildren and four great-grandchildren. ''And I have friends on the block,'' said Mrs. Toner, who has lived in her four-bedroom house for nearly 60 years, ''which is why I don't want to move.''

docs.lead_paragraph: INTERNATIONAL A3-15 Companies Offer Price Cut For AIDS Drugs in Africa Five pharmaceutical companies are willing to negotiate steep cuts in the prices they charge for AIDS drugs in Africa and other poor regions hard-hit by the disease, the World Health Organization said in Geneva. Major Western drug companies have been under growing international pressure to make their therapies more accessible in poor areas that are grappling with the epidemic. A1 Sierra Leone Rebels Halted Forces backing the government -- a coalition of United Nations peacekeepers, Sierra Leone soldiers and a militia known as Kamajors -- appeared to push back rebels advancing on the capital, Freetown, as fighting intensified and spread. docs.lead_paragraph: Five pharmaceutical companies offered today to negotiate steep cuts in the price of AIDS drugs for Africa and other poor regions afflicted by the disease. The announcement of negotiations, to be held with the World Health Organization and other international aid groups, was made in Geneva. It followed mounting pressure on the companies -- including a personal appeal from the United Nations secretary general, Kofi Annan, at a special session on AIDS in December -- to make their therapies more accessible in Africa, Asia and other regions devastated by the epidemic.

headline.main: COMPANIES TO CUT COST OF AIDS DRUGS FOR POOR NATIONS

docs.abstract: Five pharmaceutical companies offer to negotiate steep cuts in price of AIDS drugs for Africa and other poor regions afflicted by the disease; companies have been under mounting pressure to make their therapies more accessible in regions devastated by AIDS epidemic; 50 million poor people in developing nations are infected with HIV; companies are expected to agree to cuts of 80 percent and more below their American prices; drug treatments used in United States, triple-therapy 'cocktails' that suppress replication of HIV, can cost up to $15,000 a year; five companies are Boehringer Ingelheim of Germany, Bristol-Myers Squibb and Merck & Co of US, Glaxo Wellcome of Britain, and Hoffmann-La Roche of Switzerland; companies will work with five international agencies: World Health Orgn, World Bank, Unaids, United Nations Children's Fund and United Nations Population Fund (M)
docs.snippet: Five pharmaceutical companies offered today to negotiate steep cuts in the price of AIDS drugs for Africa and other poor regions afflicted by the disease.    The announcement of negotiations, to be held with the World Health Organization and other...

docs.lead_paragraph: The Maine Legislature gave final passage yesterday to a bill that makes Maine the first state to threaten the pharmaceutical industry with price controls, which could come into force in 2003, and in the meantime effectively turns the state into a giant drug-price negotiator for about half its citizens. Gov. Angus King, an independent, signed the bill last night.

headline.main: Maine Enacts a Law Aimed at Controlling Cost of Drugs

docs.abstract: Maine Legislature gives final passage to bill that makes state the first to threaten pharmaceutical industry with price controls, which could come into force in 2003, and in the meantime effectively turns state into giant drug-price negotiator for about half its citizens; Gov Angus King signs bill; bill will create Maine Rx program that will negotiate prescription drug prices for estimated 325,000 people who are uninsured or who are not covered for prescriptions, as well as 200,000 in Medicaid and prescription drug programs for elderly (M)
docs.snippet: The Maine Legislature gave final passage yesterday to a bill that makes Maine the first state to threaten the pharmaceutical industry with price controls, which could come into force in 2003, and in the meantime effectively turns the state into a...

docs.lead_paragraph: Less than a month after signing a landmark deal that changes how it does business with doctors and consumers in Texas, the health insurance giant Aetna Inc. said today that it planned to relax some managed-care policies in Connecticut. The move is part of the company's efforts to make changes one market at a time to business practices and policies that landed Aetna and its managed-care industry peers at the center of criticism from those who say they are more concerned with profits than members' health needs.
docs.abstract: Aetna Inc says it plans to relax some managed-care policies in Connecticut; move is part of company's efforts to make changes one market at a time to business practices and policies that landed Aetna and its managed-care industry peers at center of criticism from those who say they are more concerned with profits than members' health needs; Connecticut's attorney general, Richard Blumenthal, who has been investigating Aetna, says changes are good start (S)
